Dear Elliot

I know of no relationship whatsoever between the Namban and th=
e Soten 
groups of tsuba.  The only feature that may be considered common t=
o 
them both is some evidence of a Chinese influence.  However, while 
with=
 Namban tsuba this resulted in a completely novel metalworking 
technique, =
Soten tsuba use conventional, Japanese techniques to 
illustrate historical=
 sujects which may be of Chinese derivation.  
But there a lots of differen=
ces:-

Soten tsuba came initially from a recognised 'school' of makers, 
al=
though they were later mass produced outside this.  There was never 
a reco=
gnised Namban 'school', the namban influence being ubiquitous.

Namban tsub=
a had their origin in China, were imported into Japan at 
the end of the C1=
6, and reached the peak of their popularity in the 
late C18.  Soten tsuba =
date from the early C18 and continued to be 
made, as poor quality shiiremo=
no, into the late Edo period.  
(Although I have no evidence for this, I su=
spect that many of the 
latter may also have been produced using the 'lost =
wax' method of 
casting.)

True examples of the Namban group are characteri=
sed by extensive 
openwork and undercutting, whereas with Soten tsuba, whil=
e they may 
demonstrate some degree of openwork, this is not a constant fea=
ture 
and never includes undercutting.

Namban tsuba commonly have profuse =
gold decoration, either as nunome-
zogan or fire gilding.  Soten tsuba are =
characterised by selective 
and delicate inlays of gold, silver, copper and=
 shakudo.

Soten tsuba do not demonstrate the decorartive mimi, seppa-dai a=
nd 
ryo-hitsu which characterise Namban tsuba.  Signatures, although 
admit=
tedly usually gimei, feature frequently on Soten tsuba and 
almost never in=
 the Namban group.

The design on Soten tsuba is themed, being is represent=
ative of 
specific characters or incidents, while that on Namban tsuba is 
=
purely decorative. 

No, I personally know of no relationship between the t=
wo groups.

Regards, John L.
